items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
A requirement for trustee professional development is included in Accreditation Standard IV.B.1.f, which states in part that "The governing board has a program for board development and new member orientation." While the standard does not prescribe specific training or topics, accreditation evaluation teams are prompted by the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges' (ACCJC) "Guide to Evaluating Institutions" to look for "materials from board training workshops" and to ask "What is the governing board's program for development and orientation?" and "Does the governing board development program address the need to learn about Accreditation Standards and expectations?"
	 
The district's trustees have long been encouraged to pursue professional development through attendance at local, state, and national conferences; two study sessions are scheduled as part of the governing board calendar each year; trustees are provided materials relevant to state and national education issues on a regular basis; and the mission of the Board of Trustees, which is being incorporated into board policy 2200, includes "orientation, education, and assessment of its own performance" as a Board responsibility. However, the district has not formalized through its policy a program of board development and orientation that includes specific expectations. Likewise, although trustees generally share informal reports of conferences attended at Board meetings and lately have submitted for the record written summaries of workshop participation, a mechanism for tracking progress on an ongoing basis has not been in place. To ensure that the district continues to meet or exceed standards for board development, a proposed policy regarding board education is attached for discussion. Also attached is a list of trustee professional development activities gleaned from 2013 Board meeting minutes and conference registrations that will be maintained going forward.
	 
During 2013, the Community College League of California (CCLC) introduced the Excellence in Trusteeship professional development program, which is intended to support good governance statewide as well as the efforts of individual districts to meet Accreditation Standard IV.B.1.f. Completion of the voluntary program is one way that trustees can provide evidence of ongoing professional development in areas identified by the CCLC as key competencies, including accreditation, student success, governance, fiscal responsibilities, board evaluation, ethics, and the Brown Act. Additionally, the ACCJC and the California Fair Political Practices Commission have accreditation and ethics workshops, respectively, available online at no charge.

Linda Thor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Education Code Section 76140 requires each district to establish its non-resident tuition for the subsequent fiscal year by February 1.
	 
The non-resident tuition fee is composed of two parts:  the tuition fee and an assessment for capital outlay. 
	 
For 2013/14, the base rate was set at the district rate of $129.  The capital outlay rate was set at $15, for a total of $144 (applicable to all non-resident students).
	 
For 2014/15, the statewide rate is $129 per quarter unit compared to the district rate of $132 as per the calculations on page 1 of the attached worksheet.  Under these circumstances, the district has the following options:
	 
1.  Set the rate at the statewide average rate of $129 (plus capital)
	 
2.  Set the rate at the district average rate of $132 (plus capital)
	 
3.  Option 3, as specified under Education Code Section 76140, cannot be exercised as FHDA enrollment in non-credit courses is below 10%
	 
4.  Set the rate to equal the rate of a contiguous district (plus capital)
	 
5.  No more than district average cost, no less than the state average cost (plus capital)
	 
6.  Set the rate at ‘highest years statewide average tuition.’  This rate is calculated to be $129 per quarter unit (plus capital)
	 
7.  Set the rate at no greater than 2012/13 average non-resident tuition fee of public community colleges in a minimum of 12 states comparable to California in cost of living.  This average is calculated to be $259 per quarter unit (plus capital)
	 
Upon analysis of these options, and in discussion with the Dean of International Programs, it is recommended that the base rate be set at $132 (Option 2) for 2014/15, or $3 more than in 2013/14.
	 
The 2014/15 non-resident student capital outlay fee should not exceed the lesser of $34 per quarter unit (see calculation on page 2 of the attached worksheet) or 50% of the adopted 2013/14 non-resident tuition fee of  $129, or $64.50.  We are recommending that the capital outlay fee for 2014/15 be set at $17, $2 more than in 2013/14.  Note: Since fiscal year 2010/11, AB 947 amended EC 76141 to enable community college districts to charge all non-resident students a capital outlay fee, not only those students who were both citizens and residents of a foreign country.  
	 
In summary, the rate for all non-resident students will be $132 base rate plus $17 capital rate for a total of $149 per quarter unit, representing a $5 increase over the 2013/14 rate.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, x6201/Joni Hayes x6261
Additional contact names:
 George Beers
Is backup provided?
 Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Foothill–De Anza Community College District wants to identify ways to reduce energy use and costs in its facilities through a wide range of energy projects that are eligible for funding with proposition 39 funding.  The selected firm will prepare an energy audit that will identify cost-effective energy efficiency opportunities in District buildings and will perform detailed energy analysis calculations and project funding applications in accordance with California Community College Proposition 39 Implementation Guidelines for projects at both colleges as well as for central services facilities.  
	 
On December 6, 2013, a Request for Proposal (RFP) was issued seeking proposals from the following firms who were prequalified to provide planning, engineering, and design consulting services for small maintenance, alteration, repair and upgrade projects:  CSW/ST2;  Salas Obrien;  Gayner;  Sandis;  Ati;  Interface;  Gordon Prill / BKF;  KPFF.  
Proposals were received on January 10, 2014, from three firms:  Gayner Engineers, Interface Engineering, and Salas Obrien. 
	 
A selection committee, comprised of District personnel, deliberated regarding the fee proposals, the completeness and quality of responses, the experience and qualifications of individuals assigned, and the collective firm experience as related to performance of energy audits and identification and development of energy efficiency projects.  Based upon this review, the Gayner Engineers proposal was determined to be the best value proposal when scored according to the selection criteria specified in the Request for Proposals.  
	 
Project funding is available from the FHDA 2013-14 Proposition 39 Allotment.

Charles Allen x6150

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On February 27, 2008, the board approved two five-year contracts with SunGard Higher Education (SunGardHE), including a Software License & Services Agreement and a Start-up Support / Maintenance Services Agreement, both associated with the procurement of the Banner administrative information system. The contracts covered many components in addition to Banner software including license and maintenance agreements for other software applications that integrate with Banner but are produced by different vendors. One software application was the Oracle database management system (Oracle DBMS), which is produced and licensed by the Oracle Corporation. The Banner system, a software application, requires integration with the Oracle DBMS to provide any and all of its functionality. The initial five-year Start-up Support / Maintenance Services Agreement approved by the board provided five years of services for all software products, except Oracle. Oracle was covered for only two years, through February 28, 2010.
	 
Every two years, SunGardHE sends a contract amendment to the district to continue the Oracle maintenance agreement for an additional two-year period. Accordingly, on February 28, 2010, the district signed the first contract amendment to renew the Oracle maintenance agreement for two years. Since the merger of SungardHE and Datatel, the new corporation Ellucian also sent the second two years amendment for District board approval. The board also approved the second amendment of Oracle contract on May 7, 2012, to extend it to February 28, 2014.
	 
In order to better align with the ending date of the original Banner master support contract the board approved on February 28, 2008, the district now requests board approval for this third amendment, which will provide maintenance for the Oracle DBMS software and related products for another four years, through February 2018, at a total cost of $1,227,552.

The District was successful at the election on June 6, 2006 in obtaining authorization from the District's voters to issue up to $490,800,000 aggregate principal amount of the District's general obligation bonds (“Measure C”). The election was conducted under Proposition 39, which was chaptered as the Strict Accountability in Local School Construction Bonds Act of 2000. Among the accountability requirements the District must comply with is the establishment of a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee whose duties and responsibilities are set forth in bylaws as shown on the Measure C website at http://www.measurec.fhda.edu/. The duties include the development of an Annual Report which shall be presented to the Board of Trustees in public session. The report is required to address the following:
A statement indicating whether the District is in compliance with the requirements of Article XIIIA, Section 1(b)(3) of the California Constitution; and,
A summary of the Committee’s proceedings and activities for the preceding year.
The annual report for 2012/ 2013 will be presented by Mr. Dudley Andersen, Chairperson of the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee, and can be viewed at http://measurec.fhda.edu/AR1213/.

Charles Allen, extension 6150

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Sound Fiscal Management Self-Assessment Checklist report is prepared each fiscal year by district Business Office staff as an additional step in the overall process of ensuring fiscal stability and continuous scrutiny of district business practices and operations.  Although completion of the report on an annual basis is recommended by the state chancellor's office, it is not a requirement.  FHDA chooses to produce the report each year because it is viewed by staff as a valuable tool for our own internal fiscal assessment and provides a comprehensive narrative document that is presented to both the Audit and Finance committee and the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statement number 45 requires the district to treat Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB) on an accrual basis, rather than on a pay-as-you-go basis.  As a result, the district has contracted with the CalPERS California Employers’ Retiree Benefit Trust (CERBT), an irrevocable trust, to fund the district’s actuarial accrued liability.
	 
The district’s actuarial accrued liability as of June 30, 2013 was $117,564,565.  As of June 30, 2013, the District has transferred $5,811,801 to the irrevocable trust.  The fair market value of the funds held with the CERBT as of September 30, 2013 was $8,272,288.
	 
The Adopted Budget for 2013-14 included a contribution of $1,500,000 to fully fund the Annual Required Contribution (ARC) for this fiscal year.   Staff will make this transfer of $1,500,000 to CERBT prior to June 30 2014, as reflected in the 2013-14 Adopted Budget.

 Kevin McElroy, x6201

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project scope consists of work necessary to improve the performance of the Cogeneration Heating Hot Water System at De Anza College’s Swim Center. This includes: limited re-location of piping to improve flow; cleaning and repairing strainers and the balancing valves; removing, inspecting, and cleaning the pump impeller; replacing broken thermometers; adding strainers, ports, gauges, and drains to make the system easier to inspect, clean, and balance; labeling piping; clean, flush, and treat the system; perform a system balance and raise the supply water temperature set point. 
	 
Salas O’Brien Engineers Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid Document #1674 was legally advertised on November 27 and December 4, 2013 in the San Jose Post Record.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges and was posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Four (4) general contractors attended one of the two non-mandatory bid walks that were held on December 12 and December 17, 2013. Bids were publicly opened and read on January 10, 2014, at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  One (1) contractor submitted a bid, R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors for the base bid amount of $93,820.
	 
The bid price submitted by R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors exceeds the engineer’s estimate and the project budget of $70,000.  Also, receipt of only one bid for this work does not provide the assurance desired regarding adequate competitiveness.  Therefore, the District recommends that the Board reject the bid received for Bid #1674, Swim Center Cogeneration Heating Hot Water Modifications.  The District will work with Salas O’Brien Engineers to revise the scope and re-design the project for bidding at a later time. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with PCC 20651(b), reject the bid received for Bid #1674, Swim Center Cogeneration Heating Hot Water Modifications at De Anza College.

Background and Analysis:
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill, District/Central Services and De-Anza College.  Foothill Project 173, Print Shop and Plant Services Facility, will be cancelled with this transfer.
	 
De-Anza Budget Transfer #41 includes the following actions:
Transfer portion of project savings ($10,000) from Project 214, Corporation Yard, to Project 203, Baldwin Winery & East Cottage “Historic Renovation,” to pay back the previous borrowing.  (Reference DA Budget Transfer #40)
Transfer portion of project savings ($10,000) from Project 214, Corporation Yard, into Project 218, Signage and Wayfinding, to fund the project. 
Note that current budget for Project 218, Signage and Wayfinding, will have an additional funding source of $36,533.61 due to PG&E Rebates (Checks 41-42 Series I and Checks 20-21 Series II) not shown here.
Foothill Budget Transfer #43 includes the following actions:
Transfer scope and budget ($208,003) from Project 171, Loop Road Re-Alignment & Pedestrian Safety Improvements, to Project 132, Loop Road Resurfacing, for convenience of management.  This transfer will allow Project 171 to be financially closed.
Transfer a portion of project savings ($400,000) from Project 106, Modernization of Building 5700, and ($300,000) from Project 160, Physical Sciences and Engineering Center, and a portion of budget ($50,000) from Project 173, Print Shop and Plant Services Facility, to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms. 
Transfer a portion of budget ($162,167) from Project 173, Print Shop and Plant Services Facility, and ($600,000) from Project 115, Fine Arts Scene Shop, to Project 162, Parking and Circulation.  Project 173, Print Shop and Plant Services Facility, is being cancelled due to inadequate project funding to complete the full scope of the project.  A portion of the budget is being reallocated to Foothill Projects 105 and 162 (referenced above) and the remaining budget will be reallocated to District Project 801 (referenced below).  
Transfer a portion of budget ($4,000,000) from Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency, to Project 121, Library & ISC.  This long-planned transfer will augment the Library budget to cover an expanded project scope.
District/Central Services Budget Transfer #15 includes the following actions:
Transfer remaining budget ($1,500,000) of Foothill Project 173 and ($2,000,000) District Project 899, District Program Contingency – Property Acquisition, to District Project 801, Property Acquisition (Foothill De-Anza Education Center Project), to augment the budget of that project in order to align funding with the project scope and current cost estimate.

Charles Allen
